Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2015 08:07AM kpmacmill wrote: I'm done!!!!! Yippeee!!! Just finished my last treatment, 30 total - 23 whole breast and 7 boosts. My skin is already starting to fade from the whole breast tx. I didn't have any skin issues really. Very, very red which has turned brown, but it never hurt. The only area where I got raw was my clavicle, and after a couple days of covering it with a Mepilex pad and aquaphor, it started to heal up. I feel very, very lucky. Good luck to those still finishing up, I hope it goes by fast.
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2015 07:40AM kpmacmill wrote: Well, I've made it through 15/30 rads now without too many SEs, mostly starting to get red and very freckled in the treatment area. ckr1956 - I've worked full time all through chemo (with a day off here and there) and also through rads. After two weeks or so of rads, I starting feeling fatigued around 5pm, so at least it was at the end of the work day. Still, not as bad as the chemo fatigue. JeniferE - I'm doing the breath hold, and while I despise it, I got used to it after a week or so. My center uses the SDX Spirometric Motion Management System (you can google it), so I have a tube in my mouth, clip on my nose and goggles on - not fun for the claustrophobic. Luckily, I found out I won't need to use it for my 7 boosts.
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2015 07:53AM kpmacmill wrote: Chrissie - In the first week or two I had x-rays everyday, now they just do one a week to make sure everything is still lined up. I was concerned about all of the extra exposure too.
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2014 04:00AM kpmacmill wrote: Yay Coyote! Another July sister done! Thanks for sharing so much about your experience and for keeping track of here us here. I hope you enjoy some very restful holidays.
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2015 12:17PM kpmacmill wrote: Gatomal - I feel relieved, but coincidently I had my first followup appt with MO this morning, so that kinda took the place of going to rads. We'll see how I feel tomorrow when I have to get up at 6:00am to go right to work - boo. MO put me on tamoxifen, so hoping for as few SEs with that as I had with rads. As far as the fatigue everyone is discussing, I was still fatigued from chemo when I started rads, so I wasn't sure if I was tired at all from rads. After about 4 weeks of rads, I starting feeling fine, so I think it was just leftover from chemo.
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2014 11:18AM kpmacmill wrote: Hi Ladies, Joining your group today. I just went to meet with nurse and RO, then had scans and tattooing. My heart is in the way, so I'll have to hold my breath during treatment. They had me practice during the scans with a scuba-like mouth piece, a clip on my nose, and goggles on that showed a readout of my breathing. After about 10 minutes, I completely lost it. I felt so claustrophobic and made them take everything off and I started crying. They were very nice about and let me calm down for a bit before they did a final scan with me holding my breath. I have my simulation on Dec. 24th, then start 30-33 rads on Dec. 29th. - Kelly
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2014 10:36AM kpmacmill wrote: Ugghhh - had my simulation today and lost it again just like I did during the scans last week. I just can't handle the breath-holding apparatus and clip on my nose - I feel like I can't breathe. We had to stop and start all over again when I started crying. I made it though, and now that I did, I think I will be ok for my first rad on Monday. I know I am strong after all I've already been through, and I'm not going to let this bring me down! I will look at this as a challenge from here on, and I love a challenge. Happy Holidays to everyone! Kelly
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2015 10:01AM kpmacmill wrote: I had my first mammogram at the end of June. They also told me there would be lots of extra views. It hurt a bit, but was nothing compared to what I'd already been through. At the time my breast was still hard and swollen. Apparently the tissue was fibrotic, so I went to a lymphadema specialist for several weeks where she massaged my breast tissue and did some lymphatic massage to drain any extra fluid which helped a great deal. Now that the swelling is down, it appears that my breast implant (from before cancer) may have shifted or has capsular contracture from the rads...sigh...it's always something ain't it??
Posts.Title: Winter rads 2014-2015 ILCMom WndrWoman

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 12:52PM kpmacmill wrote: Here I am 9 weeks PFC after a trip to the hairdresser for semi-permanent color. My hairdresser really fluffed it up.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2015 08:24AM kpmacmill wrote: I've had my hair professionally colored twice now, once at 9 weeks PFC and again at 15 weeks (I'm at 20 weeks PFC now), with a semi-permanent color and had no problems whatsoever. My hairdresser has had a lot of clients who went through chemo and no issues with semi-perm coloring. She won't use any peroxide or anything to lift color, so I will have to stay brown with no highlights for a while, but at least the grays are covered.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2015 06:38AM kpmacmill wrote: You look like a model Pamela! Did your hair come back straight like it is in the picture? Mine is so wavy and curly at 7 mos PFC, I just want my straight hair back. I do currently have hair extensions, though, because I couldn't stand the short hair for another minute, but I have to keep taming down my own curly pieces that poke through.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 01:42PM kpmacmill wrote: CassieCat - It took about 4 weeks PFC for the top to start coming in. My hair started growing back during Taxol, so I had some on the sides and back before I was done with chemo (though next to nothing on top). That helped I'm sure. It is coming in fast thank goodness!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 03:09PM kpmacmill wrote: In two weeks, I bet it will be all filled in. Your lashes and brows are ahead of where mine are!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2015 08:57AM kpmacmill wrote: I'm having the same problem Windgirl. I'm about 20 weeks PFC and my hair is coming in very well, but my eyebrows are very sparse and they were already sparse before chemo. I still have to draw them in everyday or I look like an alien. And just recently, both lashes and brows have been falling out, but there seem to be hairs right behind them filling in. My eyelashes are weird - they are long but very straight and don't really hold a curl like they used to. I have been using Latisse on lashes and brows for months, but can't say I see a big difference.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2015 08:35AM kpmacmill wrote: HomeMom - My hairdresser used semi-perm. color on my hair at 9 weeks PFC - no issues. I didn't ask my MO about it. I'm not sure what the concern is. My hairdresser has treated many women post-chemo and has had no problems coloring hair with semi-permanent color. I will say that my hair came out a shade lighter than how it used to come out before chemo, so be aware of that.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2016 11:30AM kpmacmill wrote: My eyelashes fell out 3 times and my brows twice following chemo. My brows are still very bare, and after giving it a year, I just had them tattooed a week ago. My eyelashes are thick but too short to curl, so I'm trying Latisse now for them.
